body.p:
Many thanks for your kind attention
in forwarding me the books for our newly established Sunday School.
Mr J H Joseph having some time back sent me a parcel of such
books, I shall not require for the present any others there one or two
dozen of Pykes Catechism which I have requested Miss Gratz in the
enclosed note (which I must ask you to to hand her) to let us have.
I am sorry that I did not hear from you by mail as you
intended I should, but am more sorry that the cause was
indisposition. I sincerely hope, dear friend that you are more
perfectly well and able to apply yourself to your usual labors.

I was not a little surprised at your remarks on my
article “? ? & their opponents,” you say—“the theme,” our
opponents' admits of a much larger elucidation than you have
yet given it. You surely must have found (if you went through
the commencement of the article) that I write “I shall reserve what
I have to say until I bring forward the quotations I speak of”
It does appear to me that you judge too hastily when you
condemn one (friendly enough I know) for not doing what
cannot be done at once but is proposed to be done in the course
of the article. I start with propositions that Hebrew authors
have been maligned abused and misrepresented now as friends would
not do this for there they must ergo have opponents, I quote
from P? & Eregoire 2 grossly illiberal one ? attacks
in proof, reserving for hereafter other illustrations and proofs of

my proposition. I begin with a quotation from Peritsol? as one,
when I have concluded my quotation I shall add some more
remarks which I had intended writing in explanation, and
which would embrace the objection you make or suggest against
my course viz of “selling the point in an off hand manner
which may do very well for an orator but not in a philosophical inquiry,”
Now I have no wish to settle the point in this way and so you
shall see, and indeed I think the lengthy apology I make for
a chapter that Peritsol? never should have written is a proof of
this. In short and in conclusion. I say Hebrew writers have
been misrepresented and I prove it by quotations from those
who have attacked them, their opponents, and let this be
enough on a subject that can't be over and above interesting
to you.

I feel proud of your good opinion in thinking I am qualified
to refute what able and learned tho bejothed men have brought
against our writers and Rabbis. Although I am aware (thank
God for enlightening me) that I am not “of the class Hebrew” still
I have sufficient common sense to know that there are others more
qualified for such a taste and nothing would give me greater pleasure
than to see yourself and many others in America set about it.
I only want the credit for suggesting such an employment if
it deserve any, and if it do not then I dont want any. I am
very well convinced that all you write is based on good feelings
towards me, and I would not have you understand anything else from what I have written above. I am not too proud
to receive suggestions from you tho' I might be from ours
I don't mind the stroke of the hour but I dont like the
kick of the ass. ? in the latter case I always feel

I gave your respects best regard compliments & I was going
to say love, to the ladies and some of these to Dr. & Mrs David
By the way the latter may ? say Hebrew.
Mrs A H David presented her lord this morning with another son and heir.

I could not communicate with my friend or any one else in
London competent to undertake the office of Hazan for Richmond
unless I was aware of all particulars. You say the salary and
perquesites would probably be £200 stlng?. What is the actual
salary? Would they pay his passage out from England? Would
they elect him for life? What are the number of families belonging
to the P. Congregation? Are there fees for marriages etc? Does the Congreg
provide a dwelling house for him? and are rents high? These are
questions it appears to me that the applicant should be enlightend
on, and if you will answer them to me in your next favor
(which I hope will be soon) I would write “right off” to England
It would be as well to say whether they require a married man
and whether in case there is no house of the Cong whether he could
board out. By the way, how comes it that Mr Lyons has
left, and why would not his congregation take him back. I
understood he was much liked there.

You omitted sending me a double number of the Oc containing
my article. I have therefore requested Mr Joseph to send me one

There is nothing of interest to write you just now, so I conclude
expecting to hear from you soon I am dear Friend

Please send me an extra No next time—
I will send you in the course of next week
a lecture for the Passover, if published let it
be in the No just before Hebrew, if you can't
publish it then, don't publish it at all.
